facts.text: Petition No. 135 of 1950 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for writ of certiorari and prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 135 of 1950. Application under Art. 32 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of a writ of certiorari and prohibition.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 12, 1951 by DAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. january 12. The Judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by DAS J -- This is an application under article 32

facts.text: No serious controversy as to the material facts.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberserious companytroversy as to the facts material for the purposes of this application. They are shortly as follows

facts.text: On May 5, 1948, Rulers of eight Punjab States including Patiala and Nabha entered into covenant with concurrence of Government of India to form PEPSU.

anchor.surface_text: On May 5, 1948, the then Rulers of eight Punjab States including. Patiala and Nabha with the companycurrence and guarantee of the Government of India entered into a companyenant agreeing to unite and integrate their territories in one State

facts.text: Ruler of Patiala became first Raj Pramukh for lifetime per Article III of covenant.

anchor.surface_text: By article III  6  of the companyenant the then Ruler of Patiala became the first President or Raj Pramukh of the Council of Rulers and he is to hold the office during his lifetime.

facts.text: Rulers to hand over administration by August 20, 1948 per Article VI; rights vest in Union.

anchor.surface_text: Article VI of the companyenant is as follows -- The Ruler of each Covenanting State shall, as soon as may be practicable, and in any event number later than the 20th of August, 1948, make over the administration of his State to the Raj Pramukh, and thereupon,

facts.text: PEPSU inaugurated on July 15, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: This Union was inaugurated on July 15, 1948, and the Raj Pramukh thereafter took over the administration of the different Covenanting States.

facts.text: Administration of Nabha State taken over by Raj Pramukh on August 20, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Administration of Nabha State was taken over by the Raj Pramukh on August 20, 1948.

facts.text: On August 20, 1948, Raj Pramukh promulgated Ordinance No. 1 of 2005 (PEPSU Administration Ordinance, 2005).

anchor.surface_text: On the same day the Raj Pramukh, in exercise of the powers vested in him, promulgated an Ordinance  No. 1 of 2005  called the Patiala and East Punjab States Union  Administra- tion  Ordinance, 2005.

facts.text: Ordinance No.1 of 2005 extended Patiala laws to covenanting states from takeover date, repealed others except pending proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: 1.  2  It shall extend to the territories included in the Covenanting States on and from the date on which the administration of any of the said State or States has been or is made over to the Raj Pramukh. 2. As soon as the administration of any Covenanting State has been taken over by the Raj Pramukh as aforesaid, all laws...

facts.text: Notification No.35 dated 27-5-05/11-9-1948 notified Patiala Income-tax Act of 2001 effective August 20, 1948 in covenanting states.

anchor.surface_text: A numberification  No.35 dated 27-5-05/11-9-1948  was issued over the signature of the Revenue Secretary numberifying that the Patiala Income-tax Act of 2001 and the Rules there- under had companye into force in the various Covenanting States from August 20, 1948,

facts.text: No income-tax law in Nabha State prior to August 20, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that prior to that date there was numberlaw in the Nabha State imposing income-tax on the subjects of that State.

facts.text: On November 14, 1948, Commissioner of Income-tax issued Notification No. 4 dated 29-7-2005 for assessment of Nabha persons under Patiala IT Act 2001.

anchor.surface_text: On November 14, 1948, the Commissioner of Income-tax issued a Notification  No. 4, dated 29-7-2005  intimating that persons belonging to the Cove- nanting States of Nabha and Nalagarh would be assessed to income-tax under the Patiala Income Tax Act, 2001.

facts.text: On February 2, 1949, Ordinance 1 of 2005 repealed by Ordinance No. XVI of 2005.

anchor.surface_text: on February 2, 1949, Ordinance 1 of 2005 was repealed and replaced by Ordinance No. XVI of 2005 promul- gated by the Raj Pramukh

facts.text: Ordinance No.1 of 2006 (Finance Ordinance) promulgated on April 13, 1949, amended Patiala IT Act including sections 3,34, new 23B.

anchor.surface_text: There was another Ordinance to which reference has to be made, namely, Ordinance No. 1 of 2006 called the Finance Ordinance promul- gated on April 13, 1949, which came into force on that very date. Section 5 of that Ordinance introduced several amend- ments to the Patiala Income Tax Act, 2001.

facts.text: Petitioner resident of Ateli, Mohindargarh (formerly Nabha, now PEPSU), carries business as Raghunath Rai Ram Parshad, never paid income-tax as none in Nabha.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a resident of Ateli in the district of Mohindargarh number in Pepsu but which formerly formed part of the Nabha State. The petitioner has been carrying on his business at Ateli for a number of years under the name and style of Raghunath Rai Ram Parshad. He never paid any income-tax

facts.text: On October 20, 1949, petitioner served notice under sections 22(2) and 88 of Patiala IT Act for year 2006 (13-4-1949 to 12-4-1950).

anchor.surface_text: On October 20, 1949, the petitioner was served with a numberice under sections 22 2  and 88 of the Patiala Income Tax Act, 2001, requiring him to submit a return for the Income Tax year 2006  13-4-1949 to 12-4- 1950

facts.text: Petitioner filed return on December 4, 1949 for year 2006, assessed on February 14, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, on December 4, 1949, filed his return for the year 2006 and on February 14, 1950, he was assessed to income-tax.

facts.text: On May 23, 1950, notice under section 34 for year ending Chet 2005 (previous year 2004).

anchor.surface_text: On May 23, 1950, the petitioner received a numberice under section 34 calling upon him to file his return for the year ending the last day of Chet 2005, i.e., for the year 13-4-1948 to 12-4-1949.

facts.text: On July 9, 1950, petitioner petitioned ITO not to proceed with 2005 assessment; on July 13, 1950 assessed best judgment under s34(4) r/w s22(4).

anchor.surface_text: It ap- pears that the petitioner along with other assessees of Ateli and Kanina submitted a petition before the Income Tax Officer on July 9, 1950, asking him number to proceed with the assessment for the year 2005 but on July 13, 1950, the Income Tax Officer assessed him

facts.text: Petitioner approached Income Tax Commissioner and Central Board of Revenue without success; no formal appeal filed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner along with other asses- sees similarly situated moved the Income Tax Commissioner and the Central Board of Revenue, New Delhi, but without any success. No formal appeal under the Patiala Income Tax Act appears to have been filed

facts.text: Petition filed in Supreme Court on August 10, 1950 under Art 32.

anchor.surface_text: On August 10, 1950, the petitioner filed his present petition before this Court under article 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: During pendency, notice under s46 for penalty if tax not paid.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this petition the income-tax authori- ties have issued a numberice under section 46 intimating that penalty will be imposed if the tax was number paid up.

facts.text: Petitioner claims discrimination: Nabha people taxed at Patiala rates pre-Aug 20, 1948 while Kapurthala at lower old rates.

anchor.surface_text: It is there stated that for the assessment year 2005, in Kapurthala the assessees whose cases were pending on August 20, 1948, were assessed under the Kapurthala Income Tax Act at rates fixed thereunder but that for the assess- ment year 2006 the provisions of the Patiala Income Tax Act

facts.text: No pending assessments in Nabha on Aug 20, 1948 as no IT Act there.

anchor.surface_text: No case of assessment was pending as against any Nabha assessee on August 20, 1948, for there was numberIncome Tax Act in Nabha prior to that date

facts.text: Court finds no discrimination under Art 14.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner has been denied the fundamental right of equality before the law and the equal protection of the laws guaranteed by article 14 due to discriminatory application of income tax rates for periods prior to August 20, 1948 between Nabha and Kapurthala assessees

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the petitioner in the first place is that he has been denied the fundamental right of equality before the law and the equal protection of the laws guaranteed to him by article 14 of the Constitution. His grievances are formulated in paragraphs 10 and 11 of his petition. It is said that while the people of Kapurthala which is included in Pepsu have been asked to pay income-tax for the period prior to August 20, 1948, at the old rate fixed by the Kapurthala Income Tax Act which was lower than the rate fixed by the Patiala Income Tax Act, 2001,

issues.text: Whether the assessment of tax on the petitioner's income which accrued prior to August 20, 1948 was illegal and not authorised by the Ordinances, thereby threatening to invade the petitioner's fundamental right to property under article 31(1)

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Tek Chand appearing in support of the petition next contends that the administration of Nabha State having been taken over by the Raj Pramukh only on August 20, 1948, and the Patiala law including the Patiala Income Tax Act, 2001, having been brought into operation on and from August 20, 1948, the assessment of the tax on the petitioners income which accrued prior to August 20, 1948, was wholly illegal and not authorised by the said Ordinances and the State by insisting on collecting the tax so illegally assessed was threatening to invade the petitioners fundamental right to property guaranteed by article 31 1  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The petitioner has been denied the fundamental right of equality before the law and the equal protection of the laws guaranteed by article 14 because Nabha residents are taxed at higher Patiala rates for period prior to August 20, 1948, while Kapurthala residents at lower old rates.

arguments.court_reasoning: No discrimination because no pending assessments in Nabha due to absence of prior IT law; any difference due to reasonable classification of assessees based on pending proceedings, permissible under Art 14.

arguments.claim: For assessment year 2005 in Kapurthala, assessees with cases pending on August 20, 1948 were assessed under old Kapurthala IT Act rates; for 2006, Patiala IT Act rates applied uniformly across PEPSU including Kapurthala.

anchor.surface_text: It is there stated that for the assessment year 2005, in Kapurthala the assessees whose cases were pending on August 20, 1948, were assessed under the Kapurthala Income Tax Act at rates fixed thereunder but that for the assessment year 2006 the provisions of the Patiala Income Tax Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 22 4  of the Income Tax Act. The petitioner along with other asses- sees similarly situated moved the Income Tax Commissioner and the Central Board of

arguments.court_reasoning: Allegation not denied in reply affidavit, taken as correct; explains application of proviso to pending proceedings.

arguments.claim: The discrimination, if any, arises not from ordinances but from absence of IT Act in Nabha leading to no pending cases; provision for completing pending proceedings under prior law is reasonable classification permissible under equal protection clause of Art 14.

anchor.surface_text: No case of assessment was pending as against any Nabha assessee on August 20, 1948, for there was no Income Tax Act in Nabha prior to that date and, therefore, there could be no occasion for completing any pending proceedings against any of such assessees. In the premises, there can be no grievance by them on the score of discrimination. The discrimination, if any, was not brought about by the two Ordinances, but by the circumstance that there was no Income Tax Act in Nabha and consequently there was no case of assessment pending against any Nabha assessees.

arguments.claim: Administration of Nabha taken over only on August 20, 1948, Patiala IT Act extended from that date; thus assessment of income accrued prior to August 20, 1948 is wholly illegal, not authorised by ordinances, and collection threatens property right under Art 31(1).

arguments.court_reasoning: Art 31(1) concerns deprivation other than by taxation; taxation protected directly by Art 265, not a fundamental right enforceable under Art 32.

arguments.claim: Art 31(1) reproduces s.299(1) GIA 1935; but taxation distinct, protected separately by Art 265 to avoid redundancy; collection of tax not deprivation under Art 31(1).

anchor.surface_text: Article 31 1  runs as follows No person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law. It will be noticed that clause  1  reproduces subsection  1  of section 299 of the Government of India Act, 1935, without the words in British India. Reference has next to be made to article 265 which is in Part XII, Chapter I, dealing with Finance. That article provides that no tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law. There was no similar provision in the corresponding chapter of the Government of India Act, 1935. If collection of taxes amounts to deprivation of property within the meaning of article 31 1 , then there was no point in making a separate provision again as has been made in article 265.

arguments.claim: Protection against unauthorised taxation under Art 265 not enforceable under Art 32 as it is not a fundamental right.

anchor.surface_text: Article 265, not being in Chapter III of the Constitution, its protection is not a fundamental right which can be enforced by an application to this Court under article 32. It is not our purpose to say that the right secured by article 265 may not be enforced. It may certainly be enforced by adopting proper proceedings. All that we wish to state is that this application in so far as it purports to be founded on article 32 read with article 31 1  to this Court is misconceived and must fail.

holdings.text: The grievance of the alleged infringement of fundamental right under Article 14 is not well-founded at all.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the grievance of the alleged infringement of fundamental right under Article 14 is not well-founded at all. Dr. Tek Chand appearing in support of the petition next contends that the administration of Nabha State having

holdings.reasoning_summary: No discrimination because no pending assessments in Nabha (no prior IT law), unlike Kapurthala; proviso saving pending proceedings creates reasonable classification of assessees permissible under Art 14 equal protection.

holdings.text: Clause (1) of article 31 must be regarded as concerned with deprivation of property otherwise than by the imposition or collection of tax, for otherwise article 265 becomes wholly redundant.

anchor.surface_text: Article 31 (1) runs as follows No person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law. It will be noticed that clause (1) reproduces subsection (1) of section 299 of the Government of India Act, 1935, without the words in British India. Reference has next to be made to article 265

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 31(1) reproduces s.299(1) GIA 1935; taxation separately provided in Art 265 (absent in GIA); harmonious construction avoids redundancy; analogy to US law distinguishing taxation from eminent domain/police power.

holdings.text: The protection against imposition and collection of taxes save by authority of law directly comes from article 265, and is not secured by clause (1) of article 31.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the protection against imposition and collection of taxes save by authority of law directly comes from article 265, and is not secured by clause (1) of article 31. Article 265, not being in Chapter III of the Constitution,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual protection in Art 265 for taxation; Art 31(1) for other deprivations; confirmed by constitutional structure and absence of equivalent in GIA 1935.

holdings.text: Article 265, not being in Chapter III of the Constitution, its protection is not a fundamental right which can be enforced by an application to this Court under article 32.

anchor.surface_text: Article 265, not being in Chapter III of the Constitution, its protection is not a fundamental right which can be enforced by an application to this Court under article 32. It is not our purpose to say that the right secured by article 265 may not be enforced.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 32 enforces only Chapter III fundamental rights; Art 265 in Part XII Finance, so alternative proceedings required.

holdings.text: This application in so far as it purports to be founded on article 32 read with article 31(1) to this Court is misconceived and must fail.

anchor.surface_text: All that we wish to state is that this application in so far as it purports to be founded on article 32 read with article 31(1) to this Court is misconceived and must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition under Art 32 invoking Art 31(1) for tax claim misconceived as tax protection via Art 265 not fundamental right; no Art 14 violation.

anchor.surface_text: All that we wish to state is that this application in so far as it purports to be rounded on arti- cle 32 read with article 31 1  to this companyrt under article 32 is misconceived and must fail.

outcome.relief_summary: Application under Article 32 read with Article 31(1) is misconceived and must fail; no infringement of Article 14
